{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-207-12-B |Item_parent=Intra-thoracic lumps and masses in children and adults |Item_parent_short=Opacities and intra-thoracic masses in children and adults |Rank=B |Title=Know the main diagnostic hypotheses for mediastinal anomalies according to topography in children |Description=None |Rubric=Etiologies |Contributors=Stéphanie Luzi,Mathieu Lederlin |Order=12}} The main causes of mediastinal mass in children are listed according to their topography in the following table:
{| class="wikitable" | colspan="2" |'''Anterior mediastinal lesions'''' |- | rowspan="2" | |Thymic tumours (benign hyperplasia, lymphoma, thymoma) |- |Germ cell tumours (mature teratomas, dermoid cysts, malignant germ cell tumours) |- | colspan="2" |'''Medium mediastinal lesions'''' |- | rowspan="4" | |Adenopathies (lymphomas, tuberculosis...) |- |Bronchogenic cysts |- |Oesophageal duplication |- |Vascular tumours |- | colspan="2" |'''Posterior mediastinal lesions'''' |- | rowspan="2" | |Neurogenic tumours (neuroblastomas, ganglioneurobastomas, neurofibromas) |- |Meningoceles |}

question.question: What are the main causes of mediastinal mass in children, listed according to their topography?
question.option_a: Thymic tumours (benign hyperplasia, lymphoma, thymoma) and bronchogenic cysts are located in the anterior mediastinum.
question.option_b: Adenopathies (lymphomas, tuberculosis...) and neurogenic tumours (neuroblastomas, ganglioneurobastomas, neurofibromas) are located in the anterior mediastinum.
question.option_c: Germ cell tumours (mature teratomas, dermoid cysts, malignant germ cell tumours) and bronchogenic cysts are located in the posterior mediastinum.
question.option_d: Neurogenic tumours (neuroblastomas, ganglioneurobastomas, neurofibromas) and vascular tumours are located in the anterior mediastinum.
